title: When will the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) next screen two million or more travelers in a single day?
preds: Daily "Total Traveler Throughput" trends seem lesslikely two million or more traveler before September 1st. https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
Incremental update. Not trending strong enough to reach 2 million.
Hasn't even broken 900k yet and we're nearing September 1st. https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
Updating from 0/0/0/1/99. Highest so far is 862k, yesterday.
Based on the latest trends, it's not looking like TSA will come close to screening even one million.

We're already at 12 August, and the TSA has yet to screen more than about 800K in a day (and that was a big day that made news in aviation circles). I don't think we'll crack the 1M mark before 1 September, much less the 2M mark. There are a lot of factors influencing this assessment. In no particular order: high jobless rates have reduced discretionary income for travel; continuing bans on American travelers overseas has caused many folks to cancel flights out for vacations; some are reluctant to travel domestically due to infection spikes in other states, and domestic traveler two-week quarantines imposed by various states, etc.; and many businesses have moved toward online meetings rather than travel, further reducing demand for flights. I don't see any of those factors improving enough in the next two-three weeks to get us to 2M travelers a day.

Looking at TSA travel numbers and correlating a strong association with COVID-19 and the down turn in TSA Screening numbers,  I see little changing in the factors that are driving down TAS Screening numbers  because I see no evidence that the pandemic will be resolved by September 1.
I didn't realize this data existed for the public, but it seems useful to be familiar with it.
Updating from 0/0/0/5/95 due to passage of time. Hit 831k yesterday, 800k the Sunday before, and 750k the Sunday before that. So it seems unlikely we'll even hit 1M this month.
Uninformed opinion that we have until next year until vaccine produced, add time for people to vaccinate, and more time for narrative/sentiment to change in a positive direction toward air travel.
TSA numbers are relatively flat and much below 2 million
Only at between 500K and 750K as of 7/31.

Incremental update.  TSA has hit 750k four times in July (most recently 26 July 2020). At this pace, they won't exceed  2 million in the next 35 days. COVID-19 is still surging in several states, and MLB is cancelling games.  Leaving at 2%, mostly for "back to school" and unknown scenarios, but will decrease it quickly.
Seems very unlinkely that the number of travelers will almost triple within ~1 month
Updating from 0/0/0/10/90 since it's been at least 3 weeks with no real change in daily numbers.

I am not changing my forecast, but for those interested in following this topic beyond this question, OAG is reporting that the four major US airlines are planning on operating about half their capacity for the Winter 2020 schedule. https://www.oag.com/blog/oag-coronavirus-update-week-twentyseven
The numbers have stayed quite low ever since the pandemic started. Two million a day would imply everything is back to normal. I don't see that happening until mid 2021 at the earliest.
Updating from 0/0/0/12/88 due to another weekend going by without a very substantial increase over the previous weekend (currently at ~750k, like last weekend).
While we have this pandemic and no vaccine; people are not willing to travel unless necessary. Airports are and will be a very low capacity 50% or less for a while.
Again - the epidemic is getting much worse
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
Travel throughput went from around 100k at beginning of may to 500k at middle of july. At this rate it would be after september before traveler count passes 2M.
Not going to happen unless a vaccine is put on the market prior to end of time frame.
Is it going from 700K to 2M in 46 days with number of Covid-19 cases as high as never before? No way.

Updating from 0/0/1/14/85 as we are halfway through July and at present we'd need a ~2.7x increase in just 4 weeks, whereas we are heading in the opposite direction, with new shutdowns. So ruling out July. For August to happen we need ~15% growth a week, every week until late Aug. This would be more or less in line with previous growth but unlike the spread of the virus, there's no obvious reason why growth in air travel should be exponential. (Could be slower, or faster?) Removing a couple % from August as we've not had this kind of growth in the past week.
While we have this pandemic and no vaccine; people are not willing to travel unless necessary. Airports are and will be a very low capacity 50% or less for a while.
There is NO way, millions of people are flying anytime soon.
Updating from 0/1/3/12/84. Obviously June didn't happen, and July 4th peak was 760k. Leaving 1% for July as "you never know", and upping August from 12% to 14% as the upward trend has continued.

764,761 throughput in peak as of 02 July 2020.
Had expected way more.

tsa ceased to report altogether after 02 July's report for 01 July 2020. I wonder if this suggests a higher than expected "Total Traveler Throughput" than expected ahead of 4th of July, and maybe higher than current checkpoint capacity.
Very unlikely to jump from 625k to 2 million in next 2 months. Keeping the forecast same

Holding steady at 600,000 plus but new surge effect? Airlines advertising heavily. People seem to be congregating and without masks so might be willing to risk flying. If he reaches iver a million will consider changing this.

Currently around 625k, and at about 300k at the beginning of June [1]. They have been hanging around 600k for the last 10 days or so, as the cases have surged in FL, TX and CA. With those high-population places having heavy caseloads, it is likely to lead to this number holding where it is, or perhaps decreasing until the states get things under control.  We might see the 2 - 3 week doubling timeframes the data shows in May and June, if they do, but, frankly, that seems unlikely. Dropping all into the last bucket. [1] https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
maintaining current forecast. The airlines may open and offer full capacity but the fears of COVID have yet to be sufficiently mitigated.

Day of 600,000 plus and I can see a million or more but as coronavirus ramps up it will probably decrease. Add in Europe and Canada says keep out.  Maybe around the holidays in the fall it will hit it if coronavirus under control.
Moved it out because of the EU decision not to allow US citizens in for now.  Plus the increase of cases leading (one would think if everyone was logical) to fewer people willing to travel.
Incremental update. On Mon 22 Jun 2020, TSA reported over 600K travelers for first time since March 19.
I’d feel comfortable saying not until well into next year.

Updating from 0/5/5/10/80 mainly to downgrade June. There is some wrong data in my original forecast [1] (mainly the % of business travelers is way off, I figured it to be ~45% but it's more like ~8%) but I don't have time to really think about it hard right now. I had given June 5% as fully half of the top ~15 days ever for TSA screenings had been in mid to late June [2,3] (numbers a bit inconsistent between those two, e.g. 28 June 2019 shows up in one but not the other). This is in all likelihood due to vacation travel once the school year ends. Since a lot of schools simply shut down for the year, the coordination effect was gone, but I figured a small chance due to force of habit. But now we have numbers through 21 June [4] and we have not broken 600k. We *have* seen a big increase, but it just seems impossible that we'd break 2M in the coming week. Cutting the 5% by half since about half the vacation-travel opportunities are gone, and half again because a 3-4x jump is unlikely so soon: so 1%. For July, 5 of the ~15 biggest travel days have been in July [2,3] but I believe we can discount July 4th (2 days, as most do a round trip) as it is too soon, I doubt we will see 3-4x jump in the next 2 weeks either. The other 3 of those 5 are ascribed to "summer travel". Are these return trips for the outbound trips in late June? If so, since the latter didn't happen, the former will not happen either. But why is there such coordination? It could be an uptick due to international travel, maybe school years abroad end in July? But if so, that is definitely not coming back in July. Idk, let's just reduce it to 3%. Going the other way, when I made my first forecast on this Q, we were at ~100k/day, and many of the forecasts sounded very apocalyptic, like maybe it would take YEARS to get back to 2M. But, in just 2 short months, we're up from ~100k/day to ~500k/day, I don't think a lot of people saw that coming (myself included). Others predicted the recovery would be about as quick as the downfall, but eyeballing the table at [4], the downfall was by ~20x in about a month, and the recovery (not even counting the long plateau at the bottom) has been ~5x in ~2 months. So I will up August by a little bit, from 10% to 12%. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1018229
[2] https://www.tsa.gov/news/press/releases/2019/06/27/tsa-screening-record-numbers-travelers-ahead-fourth-july
[3] https://www.tsa.gov/news/press/releases/2019/12/05/tsa-screened-record-breaking-number-thanksgiving-holiday-travelers
[4] https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
I do not see enough people wanting to travel until the covid numbers come right down.
The daily traveler  number  is not increasing that fast. The increase is expected to stall due to increase in daily number of covid cases

Increased by from 519,000 to 576,000 This Friday vs last Friday.  The weeks before were more hopeful 419,000 to 519,000, and 375,000 to 419,000 the week before, but I do not see it happening in July.  The increasing case numbers, the continued lack of customer care by airlines (token only), and the fact that the airlines are effectively laying people off mean they don't think this is happening soon either, and lead me to believe we won't see the 2 million this summer.
Current growth rate is 15% per week which would mean approx August 25th.  But increase in covid cases means reduction in air travel growth -- so later than late August.
I believe we will not see numbers that high until there is a covid vaccine

We are currently at about 1/2 million a day, double a month ago. I project it to double by mid July, then again by mid August, reaching the 2 million mark. I have extended it a bit to account for the increase in cases in some states. But last year we were at 2.6 million in June, so 2 million is still a significant decrease in travelers.
Pandemic still in full force, reducing all non-essential travel.

On 11 June, traveler throughput was over 500,000 for the first time since March. Maybe the TSA will screen 2 million people in one day before September? Most of the news and analysis I am seeing says it is unlikely, but if the numbers double again in a month, maybe it is possible. I am not revising my forecast now but sharing that travel search website Kayak is saying travel demand will probably not return to 2019 levels until 2023 (https://www.msn.com/en-us/travel/news/air-travel-rebound-still-years-away-as-virus-lingers-kayak-says/ar-BB15vbbJ). Also, Kayak released some data (https://www.kayak.com/flight-trends) showing that while flight search volume is picking up, it is still down about 50% yoy.
Last minute summer travel in more relaxed rules.  If Hawaii lifts the 2 week quarantine in July, the tourism will explode.
NO way will people want to fly in large numbers until there is a vaccine.  And that won't be until at least 2021.
Flying is expensive and the people with higher incomes are generally more educated and able to understand the higher probability of being exposed to the coronavirus during a flight and at an airport.
Cases climbing.  I ain’t flying.  And I don’t think many other people will either.  Not for awhile.

Cases rising rapidly in nearly 25 states- many chronically ill (60% US population) won’t willfully expose themselves.  Airline travel necessitates Physical closeness wit’s other travelers and touching high touch surfaces.  People will travel by car domestically for pleasure primarily.  Also car is cheaper for record numbers of unemployed Americans.  Widespread air travel likely next after therapeutics announced and/or vaccine widely available.
More flights and crews are being cut and there is no sign of the pandemic slowing. I cannot see this happening until after there is a vaccination.
Flight travel is going to take longer than this to get back to a normal pace.

Air travel will not come back to historic levels for a long time if ever.  Not only do people need a reason to travel, which they don’t unless work travel and holidays restart, but airlines have build up their capacity which will take time.  Planes that have been out of commission will need testing and safely returning, crews will need refresher training.  And this will only happen in response to demand.  So cannot see getting near 2m let alone last year levels before September.  At this point I wonder if it will ever happen given the fact that business travel is never likely to be as it was.
It’ll probably not be until January 2021
people remain leary of air travel
On June 10th, the traffic is below 400K, increasing by 3% per day. Likely to taper off 10-20% below previous levels.
People are not traveling for summer vacation. I usually travel and am not due to concerns about hotel. Staying close to home.
Business travel will remain very low; Summer professional conferences  have been cancelled. Tourism will also be very low for similar reasons-  many cancelled summer events.
I had to reread the question. I don't expect we'll be back to normal numbers until mid-2021. We would be foolish to do otherwise.
People are scared. Virus is accelerating.  Worse, airlines are not giving appropriate refunds making people less likely to book.

Norwegian - cancelled flights for already booked trips this summer. Not doing well in its “restructuring.” Still have majority of its planes grounded even though the company sold the seats and now only offering credit to passengers. Virgin Atlantic and EasyJet are also still cutting capacity even though people want to fly, offering credit for pre-booked airfare.  Desire to travel increases during summer - even during a pandemic - but not enough seats on planes. TSA mean holding steady between 300,000- 400,000 for past month.
Will not be changing until at least November if then.

I am not changing my forecast but taking fisherdbus's comment about redistributing more if screening is up to 1 million by the end of June as a reminder to keep an eye on the information and not be overconfident. I think keeping an eye on the OAG information (https://www.oag.com/blog/oag-coronavirus-update-week-twentyone) will be very helpful in forecasting this question. If there are not enough seats to fly 2 million travelers on a given day it is unlikely the TSA will screen 2 million travelers that day. OAG is reporting that US capacity for the week of 8 June is still 66% below that of 20 January.

Up to 430,000 now. Many of my older friends are going to fly in July, August. Probably be some deals. If covid increases that should scare people off and it is increasing. If that are at a million by end of June I might redistribute more.
States will continue to relax rules, and students will head back to college in the Fall.

This would mean normal flying numbers, which likely won't rebound for years, unless colleges feel safe enough to reopen which could drive numbers up exponentially. As of now the decline was exponential but the recovery has been fairly linear.

2019  had 2.3 mln  per day. So 2mln  is "full recovery".  There will be no full recovery for a while, with many companies preferring virtual meetings, and many people not risking the travel. Adventurous travelers will not replace this drop in demand. Also, the planes are re-planned for social distancing and this will impact bandwidth.
The current number is sitting at 250k per day. The number of things that would have to change by July 1st makes 2 million per day seem less likely.
353,000 about now. Climbing but unlikely to reach 2 million. Will keep watch. Gear back a little.

The US population will be worn out by late summer and will want to travel even if only locally. Combine that with Students beginning college and most large companies having put in place Covid-19 response plans there may be an uptick in travel in August. It is more likely however, there will be lasting trauma from this pandemic, as well as large scale changes for digital work meaning we may not see these same travel volumes until a vaccine is manufactured and travel and tourism ramps up again.
We've seen some days with more than 300,000 passengers recently but I still can't imagine it'll be over 2 million before August or even September.

I am not changing my forecast but sharing that aviation data consultancy OAG discusses the supply side of the equation, reporting “if we could even reach 45 million seats a week by the end of August … that would be … less than half of the January capacity.” https://www.oag.com/blog/oag-coronavirus-update-week-nineteen There is a lot of data in the article and knowing the load factor in January was 80.5% (https://www.transtats.bts.gov/Data_Elements.aspx?Data=5) can anyone help figuring out some metric to forecast the answer in part by determining if there is even enough capacity to carry 2 million travelers?

I was way too confident before. The number jumps around quite a bit, with some day to day variations close to 100,000 over the past few days. And it is generally increasing, though not too quickly. I still think the 200,000 mark will not be hit until after September first, but I have to give some weight to August and even July.
I should (and will later) do a more rigorous analysis with a normal distribution with increasing mean, but I think if the mean is close to 1.3-1.5 million, then 2 million on a given day is within the realm of possibility, basing off of the day to day fluctuations from this year and last year.
Moving more to the side of not happening
Current TSA numbers have doubled since early May. Still very far away from 2 million.  https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput

"The impact on air travel from the coronavirus will be felt for many years to come, according to the International Air Transport Association, which estimates that passenger traffic won’t rebound to pre-crisis levels until at least 2023." https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/14/coronavirus-air-travel-wont-return-to-pre-crisis-levels-until-2023-iata-chief-warns.html
I like @scoopsjonez update and am leaning toward that rationale. As of now, I'm accounting for potential false sense of security and antsy-ness leading to a fluke uptick.

Not changing my forecast but wanted to share that aviation consultancy Leeham Co. is forecasting that it “will take four to eight years before [aviation] traffic returns to pre-COVID-19 levels.” https://leehamnews.com/2020/05/11/bringing-back-long-haul-capacity-with-narrowbody-aircraft/ They are also reporting that “Southwest Airlines doesn’t see traffic returning to 2019 [levels] for five years.”

New normal will involve less air travel.  Won't change in 2020.  A full recovery would get us back to about 80% of prior level.   Will track this and if we see 1M in june, may adjust to allow for prob that a peak day at 80% prior would still get us above 2M.  Right now, I don't see that happening till 2021
scoopsjonez information is key. Thanks for the research. Read question wrong before. Not reach 2,000,000 but 2,000,000 in a single day. Only about 50,000 a day max now.

I don’t see anything pointing to a quick recovery in passenger numbers and therefore am increasing my forecast for not before 1 September. Lufthansa is saying that it will take “years until the worldwide demand for air travel returns to pre-crisis levels” (https://newsroom.lufthansagroup.com/english/newsroom/news-releases/lufthansa-group-decides-on-first-restructuring-package/s/0695cc64-1a64-4939-b409-7da5d5b2c0d3). And Boeing’s CEO is reportedly saying “airline traffic levels won’t be back to even 25% in September, and ‘maybe’ only approach 50% by the end of the year, with a return to pre-COVID-19-pandemic levels not likely for three to five years.” (Quote from article not from CEO https://www.marketwatch.com/story/airline-stocks-take-a-hit-after-boeing-ceo-warns-of-possible-industry-bankruptcy-2020-05-12).
Changing things up a bit as back to normal process is accelerating.
With a long, slow recovery in Covid cases,
bottomed out on 4/14 at 87,500. Now touching 200,000

In early March, numbers dropped below 2 million. Confidence was a lot less rattled than it is now. It will take more than a couple of months to get back to that 2m mark.  I don't think summer vacations will spark that surge this year nor will business travel ramp up sufficiently to hit that figure.
Doing between 20,000 and 50,000 a day now. At 191,000. Say 30,000 a day average just for fun. 60 days is early July.

If the "bottom is in", realizing the decrease occurred in 5 weeks, I assume the recovery would take at least twice as long as the decrease. 10 weeks from the "bottom" of 4/15 would be 8/25. Coinciding with my assumption of schools resuming on-schedule in the Fall, work travel would follow a similar schedule.

Current TSA numbers are hanging around 150k passengers per day [1]. In a survey from a couple weeks ago, 92% of companies had said that most or all domestic business travel had been cut, with corporate travel managers being very pessimistic about its return this year [2]. [1] https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/20/business/business-travel-coronavirus.html

New Harris Poll: "As of now, over half of Americans (51%) have canceled or postponed upcoming travel plans due to coronavirus (COVID-19). Seventy percent say they would not get on a plane right now, up from 61 percent 10 days ago."
Copied Crowd Forecast as a first forecast
Updating since more business travellers than I originally thought

Current nos being screened by the TSA per day is around 120k (average of last 10 days) as on 5th May 2020.  2 million + would mean 90% of normal air travel in the USA. It would be difficult to scale back to this level in the next 4 months. 95% probability that it will happen only past 1st September.

2.8mio is busiest day ever of TSA. We would need to reach more than 2/3 of that. Statistics show 12% of travelers are business, rest is personal or leisure. Will two out of three people who would otherwise travel will do so?
Economy opening so maybe earlier than thought.
Changed due to change in many states shelter in place policies.
reduced business activity; international travel restrictions will still be in place; flights will require social distancing (i.e. planes will not be operating full capacity)

Although there will certainly be an upsurge in travel at some point once things open back up, I am considering this a 99.9999% chance for 2M a day being after 1 September at this point for two reasons:  1) The continuing bad economy. The CBO has just forecast 14% unemployment rate for Q2 2020 and 16% for Q3 2020. Source: https://www.cbo.gov/publication/56335  2) The research coming out that sharing indoor air with strangers is how this thing spreads, the vast majority of the time: https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.04.04.20053058v1

A new CBS survey shows only ~15% of Americans would be comfortable getting on an airplane if stay-at-home orders were lifted. https://www.cbsnews.com/news/americans-prioritize-staying-home-and-worry-restrictions-will-lift-too-fast-cbs-news-poll/

I get the sense that (a) this thing will take a long time to stabilize given the country's size, case count, and varying policies  (b) the public will be largely traumatized by their experience and be reluctant to do non-essential travel for some time (c) the US will appear dangerous to the rest of the world so foreign travelers will remain low throughout the summer.

A COVID-19 vaccine almost certainly won't be available until a year from now at a minimum. Given that near certainty, TSA traffic in my most bullish scenario might reach 75% of its pre-COVID level by September. That puts it below even the busiest day in throughput from a year ago. This time period also excludes the holiday season.

Updating my probabilities given the recent developments/new assessment on my side:
- big events are being cancelled around the world (e.g. Octoberfest in Germany recently)
- the likelihood of a second wave is quite high once restrictions get lifted
- airlines have grounded planes and layed of employeeds, this will not get reversed immediately
- no vaccine will be available before 01 September

Note to self. Biggest TSA day in history was Dec. 1 2019.
2,870,764 passengers.
Days above 2M were common up into early March 2020.
International travel will be reduced until more testing or a vaccine is ready. It's possible the summer bump and bad policy might open it up earlier, to be revisited in a few weeks.
likely 2nd wave of cases in next 2-3 months as easing restriction causes 2nd surge.

Slight adjustment to eliminate July from estimate. Eagerness to 'open' the country will likely backfire. The portion of TSA checks that are for foreign visitors and older people seems especially likely to remain low. Last day above 2 million was 3/8.  Currently appears to have bottomed out at around 5% of that.

I love this question. So many aspects to it. 1. According to the TSA page, 1y ago we had ~2.3M travelers screened every day. But where were they going and coming from? International travel restrictions will probably recover more slowly. There are travel bans / restrictions to remove, international travel takes longer (hence riskier), and it is more expensive (and people have lost jobs and income). So it matters what % of previous TSA screens were international. Similarly, several US states have travel restrictions and self-quarantine requirements (20 by a rough count [1]); so it matters how many were coming and going to/from each state. The info on % of international screens was easier to find that I anticipated; ~23% of all passengers were international in 2019 [2]. 2. The TSA page only has info since 1 March 2020, and the info from 1y ago for the same period. But travel is heavily seasonal. Lots of people travel during (northern) summer. Currently the highest day visible on the TSA page is 2.6M, in mid-March 2019. But what was the highest number in summer 2019? Was it ~3M? Or 10M? This matters as the forecast must incorporate a baseline as well as a prediction of how the pandemic will evolve. Well, as it turns out, TSA screens are much more stable, and travel much less seasonal, than I had guessed: the top day in history was ~2.8M, just ~20% above the average of 2.3M [3]. On reflection, vacation travel is seasonal, but it probably offsets, not adds to, business travel. 3. Even after all lockdown ends, how long does it take for people to go back to previous levels of activity? The most braindead approach I can think of is to assume the recovery takes the same amount of time as the crash. Right now that would mean 41 days (after lockdown ends). Psychological factors that are hard to guess come in. What % of people will be eager to travel again? What % will take some time to enjoy their locality anew, before wanting to travel? Some polls: over 80% of Americans approve of the lockdowns, in the many ways you might ask that question [4]. About 60% are worried the US will remove lockdown too quickly [5]. For business travel: some businesses (what %?) have had to adapt to remote work, so demand will probably lessen compared to pre-corona. And across the board, *making* travel plans is substantially more complex than cancelling them, which argues for recovery being slower than crash. 4. It's all but certain that we won't have a vaccine before September. Hence resurgences of the virus will remain a concern. This creates a negative feedback loop for this question: even if we go back to (say) 1M travelers per day, that would probably lead to the virus spreading again, which would lead to another round of lockdowns, fewer people traveling, etc. Getting more quantitative... 1. The pre-coronavirus baseline is 2.3M/day; 2M is 87% of that
2. Big travel days before 1 Sep 2020 are:
....2a. Memorial weekend (25 May 2020), 2M is 72% of 2019 memorial weekend
....2b. A whole week in late June (school vacation?); 2M is ~75% of each of those
....2c. July 4th weekend? Doesn't appear in [3] but let's guess 2M is ~75% of that too
3. With the DoS level 4 global travel advisory, and all the uncertainties worldwide, I'm pretty sure international travel will not go back to half or more what it was, before 1 Sep 2020. So I claim >11% of the travel on a normal day is gone for the remainder of the question. More for the earlier periods.
4. The coordination effect of everybody travelling after the last week of school is gone, since schools have closed. So we will not see a bump nearly as pronounced around those dates as last year. The coordination effect of July 4th will still be there, as well as memorial day. However, I predict that some sizeable % of people will actively avoid crowded airports, and shift travel dates around.
5. Most international travel into the US is Mexico + Canada. US/Canada border closure has been extended until 20 May, and "undoubtedly longer" [6].
6. The fraction of business trips is ~45%: 463.6M [7] divided by 1.013B [2] in 2018. Lotta words, but what about an actual forecast? Here is my tentative timeline... MAY: Lots of places are already scheduled to be in lockdown for at least half of May. Travel will be < 50% baseline for sure. Memorial Day is too soon. Most of the 20 states with quarantine requirements will still have them, and will actively discourage travel into them on Memorial Day.
JUNE: International travel still more than 2/3 gone for sure. And business trips still down at least 50% for sure. People who travel on business are generally wealthier and less likely to be forced into risky situations. Let's say a 5% chance here that somehow one of the school-end bumps pushes us over 2M, as that is over 2 months away.
JULY: International travel still more than 1/2 gone. Business trips still down at least 25%. Let's say 5% chance the 4th of July pushes this over 2M.
AUGUST: International and business travel still below 3/4 of pre-coronavirus for sure. I don't think there are big domestic travel events in August. So give this 10% as it is further away. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/10/travel/coronavirus-us-travel-driving-restrictions.html
[2] https://www.transtats.bts.gov/Data_Elements.aspx?Data=1
[3] https://www.tsa.gov/news/releases/2019/06/27/tsa-screening-record-numbers-travelers-ahead-fourth-july
[4] https://www.newsweek.com/americans-back-national-stay-home-order-1496997
[5] https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/meet-the-press/poll-six-10-support-keeping-stay-home-restrictions-fight-coronavirus-n1187011
[6] https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/04/18/coronavirus-canada-us-extend-border-restrictions-another-30-days/5160363002/
[7] https://www.statista.com/statistics/207103/forecasted-number-of-domestic-trips-in-the-us/

1) Vaccine almost certainly won't happen that quickly. 2) Evidence so far is that survivors have only a limited immunity from being reinfected. 3) High chance of subsequent waves of infections, when looking at previous viral epidemics. 4) Experts are now saying it will take 12-24 months for travel to become safe again

According to the TSA(https://www.tsa.gov/news/releases/2019/04/30/tsa-hits-record-setting-numbers-more-108m-travelers-screened-during-spring), average daily screens amounted to 2.2 million per day in Spring of 2019. I think this number is a reasonable proxy for peak passengers screened pre-covid 19. There are two scenarios where travel statistics will return to anything resembling this peak, herd immunity or ubiquitous proliferation of a vaccine. Development of the latter is estimated to take anywhere from 1 year to 18 months. So I don't expect travel volume in the future to look anything like pre-covid 19 numbers anytime soon, definitely not anytime this year.
States have been slowly increasing the stat shut down timelines.

It will depend on when Trump opens up the borders, but also if governors allow air traffic and remove travel bans. While I see the first happening somewhat quickly there will be a lag before people start travelling again. I therefore focus my forecast on the later months and as the last period is much longer than the previous alternatives it receives outsized influence.

2M daily is roughly the normal throughput. Therefore I would currently not expect it to be reached before all travelling has resumed normal operation. This will depend on various factors; possible travel bans between states, covid-19 spread in various states (influencing the former),...

Expectation that measures will reduce new cases in the course of April. May and June recover and restart activities.
High likelihood that people will start travelling for summer vacation and July 4th weekend. >2m means less than -30% reduction vs 2019.
If this is not working out, no recovery of tsa checks before September.

2 Million is on the low end of average number of passengers in a given Mar-Apr day of 2.3M, based on 2019 figures, with the range being 2.0-2.6M. So, 2 million passengers implies that US travel is very close to being back to completely normal operations. Due to the COVID-19 outbreak, today's TSA figures are only averaging about 100K screens per day. I believe these numbers will decline further, to some degree, and then will begin to rebound as domestic travel guidelines are relaxed. Based on case numbers, I would not expect this to occur until June-July in the US, and I expect it will occur gradually, with restrictions on what percentage of flight seats can be filled, for example.  Politically, there are motivations in the US for things to go back to normal sooner, so this may be forced up a bit... but I don't think it will bring completely normal travel back. The other question is how international travel will be impacted, since some portion of those 2M passengers are not US-based, and may be restricted from leaving their home countries, thereby having an impact. I was unable to find any statistics on international visitors as as a % of TSA screens. Overall, I see low probability that 2M is hit before Sept 1 - as reflected in my estimates.

Airline capacity is likely to be down by 50% year over year through at least June. Bookings likely won’t start coming back until new cases have declined for at least several consecutive days. Most bookings will happen at least 2-3 weeks prior to travel. Corporate travel will likely lag even further as companies try to wrap their head around the medium term economic impact of the virus before ramping up travel budgets.

Who is going to book a flight to anywhere before we have a handle on prevention and cure? Going to the grocery store exposes you for 10-20 minutes to a few people. On a plane you are exposed for hours to hundreds of people going thru airports, standing in TSA lines, and sitting tied into a seat. What destination is worth it? Plus many people will no longer have the means to travel. This could be a long recovery for the airlines.

Looking at the data, the past number of people being checked is around 2.3 million, so the total number of people being checked needs to get basically to pre-COVID numbers; however, air travel in July and August is about 20% higher in July and August. I could not find the exact number of TSA checkpoint travel numbers for July and August, but I estimate them to be about 2.7 million. This means if there is only a 25% reduction in the number of flights due to COVID-19 that would get them past the 2 million mark. In addition, it doesn't have to consistently beat 2 million, and it fluctuates by plus or minus 200,000, so if the average per day got up to 1.8 million, there would probably be a day with more than 2 million checks, so a 33% or lower reduction in flights would probably be enough. A second thing we have to consider is a lot of travelers book in advance, so the number of flights probably won't recover until well after the pandemic is over. Looking at COVID-19 forecasts it is almost certain that it will still be a problem by June 1, so we can rule out the possibility of having 2 million before then. This means that June 2020 is also unlikely. The forecasts also show that it will be a problem in July; however, I don't think the forecasts are very accurate going out that far. I still seems like COVID-19 will be doing its thing at that point, but there is a chance the forecasts are wrong, so I'm giving it a 6% chance (16:1 odds). Some forecasts show the first wave being over by August, but it looks like a second wave is likely, but people might be starting to ignore travel recommendations at that point. There is some hope of things getting back to normal by August, but it still doesn't seem that likely. Also, there are lag effects like I said, so it needs to be better by the beginning of August. I'm giving it an 18% chance (4.5:1 odds). Finally, I'm putting the rest into after September 1.

Homemade model [1] that looks at linear recovery of domestic flights in China [2] to project how quickly TSA traveler throughput will increase once bottoming out (current slope: 0.05 percentage points increase each day from bottom). Assumes bottom for U.S. will be height of daily death chart from IHME projections [3] (currently 4/16). Projected mean: September 22nd
Standard deviation: 57 days (i.e. 68% of the time result will be within this many days of either side of projected mean) This looks right given this chart [4] from The Economist that shows that it took 6-7 months before airlines came back from SARS in 2003. I suspect it will likely be even longer for COVID-19.  With all my GJO projections, I've started to "extremize" my probabilities as suggested as a best practice by Tetlock's superforecaster research [5]. I'm currently extremizing by 20%. Arguments for earlier:
- domestic air travel could be re-started once virus is contained in the US (~75% of air travel is domestic if I interpret the numbers on statista correctly); reaching 80% of pre-crisis capacity would be enough to clear the 2mn threshold (2.5mn were reached several times last year around this time)
- peak travel events like travel around the 4th of July could clear the 2mn threshold
- the US government (especially Trump) have been pushing to re-open the US as soon as possible
- once the virus is contained people will swarm to airports after not having been able to travel for a while; many Q1 and a lot of Q2 holidays are being cancelled/postponed, so demand to go on holiday will be huge
- ramping test capacities still requires some time in the US Arguments for later:
- as soon as even domestic flights are allowed again (re-)spreading of the virus across the country is likely
- banning events with 50+ or 100+ people is essentially part of any hammer & dance, social distancing and controlling the virus strategy (to rule out super-spreaders); airports and flights cannot operate while these suppression and mitigation strategies are in force
- any airport operating anywhere close to full capacity would be a risk for super-spreaders; one infected person at the airport can infect several others who spread it across the country
- while the virus has not been contained completely, parts of the population will have aversion to travel, limiting the pickup in flights
- events in July/August are already being cancelled/postponed (Olympics, etc), further reducing need to travel
- when easing the restrictions restaurants, public transport, shops etc will likely be the first steps to boost the economy, mass air travel does not seem to be the highest importance (especially considering the super-spreader risk); domestic travel can at least partly be replaced via cars
